flags.title: Unpublished
flags.text: This project guide will not appear in search results but can still be viewed by anyone!

flags.title: User-Contributed Project
flags.text: This project guide is not managed by MAKE staff.

guide.introduction:
Based on a design by Rick Cavallaro & John Borton.

This simple cart is powered by the wind, and will go directly downwind faster than the wind. It’s a real mind-bender, but it’s does not represent any kind of scientific breakthrough. It’s doesn’t represent perpetual motion and it won’t make anyone millions or solve our energy problems. But it’s fun to see this thing advance on a running treadmill, and even more fun to try and understand how it works.
guide.introduction_rendered:
Based on a design by Rick Cavallaro & John Borton.

This simple cart is powered by the wind, and will go directly downwind faster than the wind. It’s a real mind-bender, but it’s does not represent any kind of scientific breakthrough. It’s doesn’t represent perpetual motion and it won’t make anyone millions or solve our energy problems. But it’s fun to see this thing advance on a running treadmill, and even more fun to try and understand how it works.

Relevant parts
  • 5x13x4mm bearings
  • 5x11x4mm bearings
  • Century Tail Gear Set Hawk #HI3075 or Heli-Max Tail Gear Set Kinetic #50HMXE9913
  • Century Tail Gearbox #HI3078 or Heli-Max Tail Gearbox Kinetic 50 #HMXE9914
  • GWS 3.35" Shock Absorbing Wheel #WH01/85
  • .062" OD x 1 -1/4" L music wire
  • Dubro Micro Lite Wheels 2" #200ML
  • 5mm OD x 4mm ID x 32" L carbon fiber tube
  • 4mm OD x 4" L carbon fiber tube
  • GWS 15"x7.5" ES Propeller #RD-1575
  • Foam-safe cyanoacrylate (super glue)
  • 1/2"x1"x1.5" HDPE bar
  • 3/8"OD x 25"L aluminum tubing
  • 6-32 x 1-1/4" bolts
  • 6-32 nuts
  • Small glass jar
Tools
  • 1/16" drill bit
  • 2.5mm hex key
  • 3/8" drill bit
  • 5/32" drill bit
  • 5/64" drill bit
  • 5mm drill bit
  • 7/16" drill bit
  • 11mm drill bit
  • 150 and 600-grit sand paper
  • Dremel or rotary tool with cut-off wheel
  • Xacto knife

parts.text: Century Tail Gear Set Hawk #HI3075 or Heli-Max Tail Gear Set Kinetic #50HMXE9913
Century Tail Gearbox #HI3078 or Heli-Max Tail Gearbox Kinetic 50 #HMXE9914
5mm OD x 4mm ID x 32" L carbon fiber tube
4mm OD x 4" L carbon fiber tube

lines.text: The bearings need to be removed of all grease to allow them to spin freely.
lines.text_raw: The bearings need to be removed of all grease to allow them to spin freely.

lines.text: Take the rubber seals off the sides of the bearing using a pin or jewelers slotted screwdriver. Stick the pin on the inner circumference of the seal and pry it off.
lines.text_raw: Take the rubber seals off the sides of the bearing using a pin or jewelers slotted screwdriver. Stick the pin on the inner circumference of the seal and pry it off.

lines.text: Your bearings might have metal  shields on the other side of the bearing so take them off by using a pin to remove the C-clip on the outer-race of the bearing. Once the C-clip is removed, the shield can be lifted up using the pin.
lines.text_raw: Your bearings might have metal  shields on the other side of the bearing so take them off by using a pin to remove the C-clip on the outer-race of the bearing. Once the C-clip is removed, the shield can be lifted up using the pin.

lines.text: Soak the bearings in acetone or turpentine in a small glass jar and swirl them around occasionally. Remove after 10 minutes and place them on paper towel to dry. When they are dry, they should not smell of the cleaning liquid.
lines.text_raw: Soak the bearings in acetone or turpentine in a small glass jar and swirl them around occasionally. Remove after 10 minutes and place them on paper towel to dry. When they are dry, they should not smell of the cleaning liquid.

steps.title: Make The Prop Shaft And Axle

lines.text: Cut 25" of 5mm-diameter carbon fiber tube for the prop shaft using the Dremel. Use masking tape to mark where to cut.
lines.text_raw: Cut 25" of 5mm-diameter carbon fiber tube for the prop shaft using the Dremel. Use masking tape to mark where to cut.

lines.text: Cut a 7" piece for the front axle.
lines.text_raw: Cut a 7" piece for the front axle.

lines.text: After any sanding, use a wet towel and wipe clean the part of any dust created by the sanding. Also, do not sand or drill near any parts. Any dust that gets on moving parts will hinder the performance of the cart.
lines.text_raw: After any sanding, use a wet towel and wipe clean the part of any dust created by the sanding. Also, do not sand or drill near any parts. Any dust that gets on moving parts will hinder the performance of the cart.

lines.text: Use 150-grit sand paper and lightly sand a quarter of the way down the prop shaft. This will allow the super glue to adhere to it when we slip our bearings over it.
lines.text_raw: Use 150-grit sand paper and lightly sand a quarter of the way down the prop shaft. This will allow the super glue to adhere to it when we slip our bearings over it.

lines.text: Slip two 5x13x4mm bearings over the shaft to check for fit. If they do not slide on, sand the shaft more and check again. Repeat until the bearings can fit over the shaft.
lines.text_raw: Slip two 5x13x4mm bearings over the shaft to check for fit. If they do not slide on, sand the shaft more and check again. Repeat until the bearings can fit over the shaft.

lines.text: Set the prop shaft aside.
lines.text_raw: Set the prop shaft aside.

lines.text: The two nylon gears have a small shoulder on the back of it. Use 100-grit sand paper to sand it off. This is to allow the gears to have a loose gear mesh for lower friction when spinning.
lines.text_raw: The two nylon gears have a small shoulder on the back of it. Use 100-grit sand paper to sand it off. This is to allow the gears to have a loose gear mesh for lower friction when spinning.

lines.text: Be careful not to damage any teeth of the gear when sanding.
lines.text_raw: Be careful not to damage any teeth of the gear when sanding.

lines.text: Take the two bearings off the prop shaft.
lines.text_raw: Take the two bearings off the prop shaft.

lines.text: Place the large gear onto the end of the prop shaft with the teeth facing outward and are flush with the end of the shaft.
lines.text_raw: Place the large gear onto the end of the prop shaft with the teeth facing outward and are flush with the end of the shaft.

lines.text: Attach the 5/64" drill bit into the Dremel and drill a hole through the carbon fiber tube where one of the hole is on gear. Drill through only one side of the tube.
lines.text_raw: Attach the 5/64" drill bit into the Dremel and drill a hole through the carbon fiber tube where one of the hole is on gear. Drill through only one side of the tube.

lines.text: Use pliers and place one of the pins that came with the gears through the large gear and the hole just drilled. Push it halfway through the shaft. This will align the hole on the other side of the gear to the hole we just drilled.
lines.text_raw: Use pliers and place one of the pins that came with the gears through the large gear and the hole just drilled. Push it halfway through the shaft. This will align the hole on the other side of the gear to the hole we just drilled.

lines.text: Drill through the prop shaft where the other hole is on the gear.
lines.text_raw: Drill through the prop shaft where the other hole is on the gear.

lines.text: Pull the pin out and pull the gear off the shaft.
lines.text_raw: Pull the pin out and pull the gear off the shaft.

lines.text: Place the bearings back onto the shaft.
lines.text_raw: Place the bearings back onto the shaft.

lines.text: Place the gear back onto the shaft like before and press the pin through the gear and the shaft so that it's flush with both holes of the gear.
lines.text_raw: Place the gear back onto the shaft like before and press the pin through the gear and the shaft so that it's flush with both holes of the gear.

lines.text: Slide the bearings apart and apply a thin layer of super glue onto the shaft between the bearings. The super glue will hold the rear bearing and prevent the gear from moving further into the gearbox, thus keeping the friction to the other gear at a minimum.
lines.text_raw: Slide the bearings apart and apply a thin layer of super glue onto the shaft between the bearings. The super glue will hold the rear bearing and prevent the gear from moving further into the gearbox, thus keeping the friction to the other gear at a minimum.

lines.text: Do not get any super glue inside the bearings.
lines.text_raw: Do not get any super glue inside the bearings.

lines.text: Before the glue dries, place the prop shaft assembly into the gear box and push the bearings in place with the gear right against the top bearing.
lines.text_raw: Before the glue dries, place the prop shaft assembly into the gear box and push the bearings in place with the gear right against the top bearing.

lines.text: Test the fit of the gear and bearings in both halves of the case.
lines.text_raw: Test the fit of the gear and bearings in both halves of the case.

lines.text: The gear should spin freely any not hit anything. If it hits some of the mold flash of the case, use an Xacto knife and remove the flash.
lines.text_raw: The gear should spin freely any not hit anything. If it hits some of the mold flash of the case, use an Xacto knife and remove the flash.

lines.text: Mark the center of axle using a piece of tape by sticking one side of the tape on the center of the axle.
lines.text_raw: Mark the center of axle using a piece of tape by sticking one side of the tape on the center of the axle.

lines.text: Slide the small gear up the axle until teeth are at the center, against the tape.
lines.text_raw: Slide the small gear up the axle until teeth are at the center, against the tape.

lines.text: Again, use the 5/64" bit and drill holes through the tube just like in step 6 and push the pin in.
lines.text_raw: Again, use the 5/64" bit and drill holes through the tube just like in [guide|503|step 6|stepid=2695] and push the pin in.

lines.text: Slide the 5x11x4mm bearing onto the axle to check for fit. We want the bearing to have a snug fit on the axle.
lines.text_raw: Slide the 5x11x4mm bearing onto the axle to check for fit. We want the bearing to have a snug fit on the axle.

lines.text: If the bearing is too loose, take it off and apply a thin layer of super glue onto the axle to build up its diameter. Spread the glue evenly around the axle and let the glue dry without the bearing on it.
lines.text_raw: If the bearing is too loose, take it off and apply a thin layer of super glue onto the axle to build up its diameter. Spread the glue evenly around the axle and let the glue dry without the bearing on it.

lines.text: If it is too big for the bearing to fit on, lightly sand down the axle with 600-grit sandpaper.
lines.text_raw: If it is too big for the bearing to fit on, lightly sand down the axle with 600-grit sandpaper.

lines.text: Insert the axle's bearing, axle, and the prop shaft into the side of the gear box with a deeper pocket.
lines.text_raw: Insert the axle's bearing, axle, and the prop shaft into the side of the gear box with a deeper pocket.

lines.text: Insert the other 5x11x4 axle bearing into the other half of the gear box.
lines.text_raw: Insert the other 5x11x4 axle bearing into the other half of the gear box.

lines.text: Slide the two halves together and check that the prop shaft spins the axle freely.
lines.text_raw: Slide the two halves together and check that the prop shaft spins the axle freely.

lines.text: Take the small bolt and a nut that comes with the gear box and screw them together at the hole near the axle using a 2.5mm hex key.
lines.text_raw: Take the small bolt and a nut that comes with the gear box and screw them together at the hole near the axle using a 2.5mm hex key.

lines.text: Determine which side the top of the gear box is by looking from the end of the prop shaft (view from behind) and turning clockwise. The axle should turn "forward" away from the prop shaft. If the axle is spinning the other way, the gear box is upside down.
lines.text_raw: Determine which side the top of the gear box is by looking from the end of the prop shaft (view from behind) and turning clockwise. The axle should turn "forward" away from the prop shaft. If the axle is spinning the other way, the gear box is upside down.

lines.text: Take a long screw and a nut from the gear box and screw them into the middle top hole.
lines.text_raw: Take a long screw and a nut from the gear box and screw them into the middle top hole.

lines.text: With the 4mm diameter carbon fiber tube, cut two 2" long pieces.
lines.text_raw: With the 4mm diameter carbon fiber tube, cut two 2" long pieces.

lines.text: Sand the ends of these tubes to give them a small taper to slide into the wheel and axle easier.
lines.text_raw: Sand the ends of these tubes to give them a small taper to slide into the wheel and axle easier.

lines.text: Slide the tubes into the wheels and then slide them into the ends of the axle. Use super glue to glue them in.
lines.text_raw: Slide the tubes into the wheels and then slide them into the ends of the axle. Use super glue to glue them in.

lines.text: Spin the wheels before the glue drys to spread the glue around.
lines.text_raw: Spin the wheels before the glue drys to spread the glue around.

lines.text: Tape over the HDPE bar with masking tape to mark where to cut.
lines.text_raw: Tape over the HDPE bar with masking tape to mark where to cut.

lines.text: At the center and 0.5" bellow the top of the bar, make a center-mark for drilling a 7/16" hole at that mark.
lines.text_raw: At the center and 0.5" bellow the top of the bar, make a center-mark for drilling a 7/16" hole at that mark.

lines.text: At the center and bottom of the block, make a center-mark for drilling 3/8" hole up through to the middle of the block.
lines.text_raw: At the center and bottom of the block, make a center-mark for drilling 3/8" hole up through to the middle of the block.

lines.text: Drill the holes and then round the corners of the block using a saw, sander, or file.
lines.text_raw: Drill the holes and then round the corners of the block using a saw, sander, or file.

lines.text: Cut off 25" of aluminum pipe.
lines.text_raw: Cut off 25" of aluminum pipe.

lines.text: Tape the end with masking tape and mark 1/4" from the end of the tube and 1.2" from that mark.
lines.text_raw: Tape the end with masking tape and mark 1/4" from the end of the tube and 1.2" from that mark.

lines.text: Drill 5/32" holes at those marks through the tube.
lines.text_raw: Drill 5/32" holes at those marks through the tube.

lines.text: Take one of the wheels off and drill through the bottom two holes on the gear box with the 5/32" bit to enlarge them.
lines.text_raw: Take one of the wheels off and drill through the bottom two holes on the gear box with the 5/32" bit to enlarge them.

lines.text: Slide two 6-32 x 1-1/4" bolts through the gear box and screw one nut onto the front bolt to act as a standoff for the tube to sit on.
lines.text_raw: Slide two 6-32 x 1-1/4" bolts through the gear box and screw one nut onto the front bolt to act as a standoff for the tube to sit on.

lines.text: Screw two more nuts over the bolts to secure the gear box.
lines.text_raw: Screw two more nuts over the bolts to secure the gear box.

lines.text: Form the frame by carefully bending the aluminum tube so that it meets close to 90 degrees and 2" from the end of the prop shaft.
lines.text_raw: Form the frame by carefully bending the aluminum tube so that it meets close to 90 degrees and 2" from the end of the prop shaft.

lines.text: Slide a 5x11x4 bearing into the bearing block into it's 11mm hole.
lines.text_raw: Slide a 5x11x4 bearing into the bearing block into it's 11mm hole.

lines.text: Slide the bearing and bearing block over the prop shaft and then slide it down onto the aluminum tube into the 3/8" hole.
lines.text_raw: Slide the bearing and bearing block over the prop shaft and then slide it down onto the aluminum tube into the 3/8" hole.

lines.text: There should be no bending force on the prop shaft from the bearing block. If there is, bend the frame accordingly to remove the force.
lines.text_raw: There should be no bending force on the prop shaft from the bearing block. If there is, bend the frame accordingly to remove the force.

lines.text: Drill a 5mm hole through the propeller.
lines.text_raw: Drill a 5mm hole through the propeller.

lines.text: Super glue the propeller to the prop shaft with the curved surface facing forward. Spin the propeller on the shaft to spread the glue evenly.
lines.text_raw: Super glue the propeller to the prop shaft with the curved surface facing forward. Spin the propeller on the shaft to spread the glue evenly.

lines.text: Tape masking tape on the low-point of the frame to mark where to drill.
lines.text_raw: Tape masking tape on the low-point of the frame to mark where to drill.

lines.text: Drill through the frame horizontally with a 1/16" bit.
lines.text_raw: Drill through the frame horizontally with a 1/16" bit.

lines.text: Drill a 5/64" hole through the 2" wheel to enlarge its hole.
lines.text_raw: Drill a 5/64" hole through the 2" wheel to enlarge its hole.

lines.text: The 2" wheels each come with two hubs that are molded into the wheel itself. Use an Xacto knife to cut them off.
lines.text_raw: The 2" wheels each come with two hubs that are molded into the wheel itself. Use an Xacto knife to cut them off.

lines.text: Drill the center of one wheel out with a 5/64" bit.
lines.text_raw: Drill the center of one wheel out with a 5/64" bit.

lines.text: Drill two hubs out with the 1/16" bit.
lines.text_raw: Drill two hubs out with the 1/16" bit.

lines.text: Take one of the hubs and using a Xactor knife, cut off most of the flat portion of the hub to be used as a spacer.
lines.text_raw: Take one of the hubs and using a Xactor knife, cut off most of the flat portion of the hub to be used as a spacer.

lines.text: Cut 1-1/4" of .062" music wire for the axle of the rear wheel.
lines.text_raw: Cut 1-1/4" of .062" music wire for the axle of the rear wheel.

lines.text: Glue on the cut hub onto one end of the music wire.
lines.text_raw: Glue on the cut hub onto one end of the music wire.

lines.text: When the glue dries, slide it onto the wheel, spacer, and frame in this order. Glue the other hub onto the end of the music wire. Once the glue dries, you've made your DDWFTTW cart!
lines.text_raw: When the glue dries, slide it onto the wheel, spacer, and frame in this order. Glue the other hub onto the end of the music wire. Once the glue dries, you've made your DDWFTTW cart!

lines.text: Use a treadmill to test the steering of your cart.
lines.text_raw: Use a treadmill to test the steering of your cart.

lines.text: Start treadmill dead-level initially (we needed phone books under the rear end of ours.
lines.text_raw: Start treadmill dead-level initially (we needed phone books under the rear end of ours.

lines.text: Run the treadmill at full speed (10 mph in our case).
lines.text_raw: Run the treadmill at full speed (10 mph in our case).

lines.text: Hold the cart by the gear box while you lower it onto the moving belt.  Don’t release it until the wheels have made good contact and the prop has come up to speed.
lines.text_raw: Hold the cart by the gear box while you lower it onto the moving belt.  Don’t release it until the wheels have made good contact and the prop has come up to speed.

lines.text: Release the cart and notice what direction it moves in.  It will likely veer to the left or right.  To fix this, very carefully bend the aluminum frame to the left or right to change the steering of the tail-wheel.  Be sure not to create load on the prop-shaft bearing during this process.  You may want to pull the HDPE bearing block off the frame occasionally to check alignment.
lines.text_raw: Release the cart and notice what direction it moves in.  It will likely veer to the left or right.  To fix this, very carefully bend the aluminum frame to the left or right to change the steering of the tail-wheel.  Be sure not to create load on the prop-shaft bearing during this process.  You may want to pull the HDPE bearing block off the frame occasionally to check alignment.

guide.summary:
Direct Downwind Faster Than The
Wind (DDWFTTW) Cart
guide.title: DDWFTTW Cart

tools.text: Dremel or rotary tool with cut-off wheel
